events.text: There is an inscription on the bookcase: [color=fuchsia]cheaters, chicanery and crookery [/color]
Somehow it seems like every single book in the library has to do with academic integrity. Strange.
It's a series of short stories recounting a number of failed attempts at cheating, chronicled by Professor Chuck
I should write some of these examples down
The book details 7 methods of cheating that you think coffee king should know:
1. bringing or accessing unauthorized materials during an examination (e.g., notes, books, or other info accessed via cell phones, computers, other technology or any other means)

2. providing assistance to acts of academic misconduct/dishonesty (e.g., sharing copies of exams via cell phones, computers, other technology or any other means, allowing others to copy answers on an exam)
3. submitting the same or substantially similar work in multiple courses, either in the same semester or in a different semester, without the express approval of all instructors
4. submitting the same or substantially similar work in multiple courses, either in the same semester or in a different semester, without the express approval of all instructors
5. submitting answers on an exam that were obtained from the work of another person or providing answers or assistance to others during an exam when not explicitly permitted by the instructor
6. submitting answers on an exam that were obtained from the work of another person or providing answers or assistance to others during an exam when not explicitly permitted by the instructor
7. altering or forging academic documents, including but not limited to admissions materials, academic records, grade reports, add/drop forms, course registration forms, etc.
